ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My speaking improved greatly after just a few months of taking this course.
I developed a great foundation in French
I learned the basics of the French language, notably basic grammar, vocabulary, sentence structure, and relative fluency speaking and listening.
Verb conjugations, present tense, past tense, basic conversations, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: the instructor engaged all students and gave constructive feedback when necessary. She was invaluable when it came to improving my speaking.
Weakness: none.

Strengths of this class include keeping students engaged in classes, the questions, discussion in French, etc. I also felt that the course being conducted entirely in French aided in becoming more comfortable with the language. A weakness, I believe, is the frequency of exams. Throughout the semester, I felt as though I was always studying for an exam instead of focusing on other assignments as well.

I found the French-in-Action series to be the weakest part of this course, I don't think it really added to my learning like the course packet did. As a complete beginner, deciphering what characters were saying was frustrating and I spent hours re-listening to the audio questions that I would have understood were they on paper.

Strengths: It is very hard to walk away from this course not having learned anything if effort is put in. There is plenty of material for reviewing in the coursepack. 

Weakness: Fitting 2 lessons into a week was challenging. The workload was intense, especially with the weekly tests, and I often felt rushed when we had 2 lessons to go through.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was much more difficult to converse with other students in French over Zoom, but some breakout rooms did aid in this a bit. The grammar lecture portion, however, fared quite well over Zoom.
I believe this course flowed just as smoothly through zoom as it would have in-person, though technical difficulties and the un-willingness of students to speak up over zoom has to be accounted for.
The zoom whiteboard and scree annotating really helped me. I'm a visual learner so seeing the words on the screen was beneficial.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who genuinely wants to learn the language because the workload can be very annoying sometimes.
I would recommend this course to another student. It is challenging, but for students who want to learn French, you learn a lot in the course.

If you are seeking to truly learn a language, I absolutely recommend this course. If you want the easy language credit, don't take this. I learned more French in a single semester than I ever would have thought possible, but it did not come easily. This is not high school language class--it's very intense and you'll have to work hard, but the results are well worth it. Also, be warned that the grading is tough, so don't expect an A.
If you want to learn French and are serious about it then yes. You will learn a lot, but be cautious because it is a lot of work.
